intro: Saussurea heteromalla, commonly known as the Tibetan safflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Asia, particularly in Tibet, Nepal, and northern India. It belongs to the Asteraceae family and is characterized by its tall, sparsely branched stems and yellow to orange composite flowers. The plant is adapted to high-altitude environments, often growing in rocky or alpine habitats. Its leaves are typically alternate, linear, and covered in fine hairs, while its roots are fibrous and well-developed. Saussurea heteromalla is valued for its medicinal properties and is used in traditional medicine for its purported anti-inflammatory and analgesic effects.
